clinical_study.brief_title: Optic Nerve Sheath Diameter Use in Pre-Eclamptic Parturient Receiving Magnesium Sulfate
clinical_study.official_title: Using Optic Nerve Sheath Diameter to Monitor Intracranial Tension in Pre-Eclamptic Parturient Receiving Magnesium Sulfate

brief_summary.textblock: the effect of MgSO4 on ONSD in severely pre-eclamptic parturients has been underestimated. Though this study aims to evaluate the effect of magnesium sulphate on raised ICP in severely pre-eclamptic parturients using ocular ultrasonography to determine ONSD as a measure of ICP.

detailed_description.textblock:
Magnesium Sulphate (MgS04) has been used for decades in obstetrics for the prevention and treatment of seizures in pre-eclamptic and eclamptic parturients. However, the effect of MgSO4 treatment on raised intracranial pressure (ICP) is still unclear.
Clinical signs of raised ICP are not specific and often difficult to interpret, especially during pregnancy and pre-eclampsia. Though the use of invasive devices is considered a gold standard in the measurement of ICP, Ocular sonography is a promising bedside tool, which serves as a noninvasive, readily available, and cost-effective means for indirectly measuring ICP.
Bedside ultrasound can be used as a point-of-care tool for rapidly measuring the optic nerve sheath diameter (ONSD), which is a validated indirect means for measuring ICP. An increase in ICP reflects as a raised ONSD since the optic nerve is surrounded by Dural sheath and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) containing subarachnoid space, which is distensible in the retrobulbar segment, particularly when CSF pressures rise.

primary_outcome.measure: Optic nerve sheath diameter (ONSD) changes following MgSO4 treatment
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline (before starting MgSO4 therapy) then at 4, 12 and 24 hours after MgSO4 apply

secondary_outcome.measure: The incidence of raised ICP in severe pre-eclampsia
Correlation of ONSD with serum magnesium levels
secondary_outcome.time_frame: at 4, 12 and 24 hours after MgSO4 therapy

secondary_outcome.measure: Correlation of ONSD with Mean Arterial Presuure
secondary_outcome.time_frame: at 4, 12 and 24 hours after MgSO4 therapy

secondary_outcome.measure: mean arterial pressure (MAP) changes following MgSo4 therapy.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline (before starting MgSO4 therapy) then at 4, 12 and 24 hours after MgSO4 therapy

study_pop.textblock: preeclampsia with severe features will be defined using the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologist Task Force on Hypertension in Pregnancy recommendation [16]; as raised blood pressure (BP) >160/110 mmHg, proteinuria more than 5 g/day, oliguria (<500 mL/day), elevated serum creatinine, intrauterine growth retardation, pulmonary edema, central nervous system manifestations (headache, visual disturbances, seizures, and stroke), hepatic tenderness, or the HELLP syndrome.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- aged18 to 40 years with
- singleton pregnancy ≥ 28weeks of gestation,
- admitted with diagnosis of severe pre-eclampsia and scheduled to receive Magnesium Sulphate therapy before delivery
Exclusion Criteria:
- Presence of ocular wound
- Prior ocular surgery
- Patient refusal
- Chronic hypertension
- Hyperthyroidism
- Presence of pre-existing chronic lung and/or cardiac diseases
- Presence of pre-existing chronic renal and/or hepatic diseases
- Presence of any chronic diseases of central nervous system.

responsible_party.investigator_title: lecturer of anesthesia and surgical ICU
